abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            Lessons learned are outlined as follows: 1) True empowerment
            of farmer groups is attained only when they are given
            control of financial resources to determine their extension
            needs. Technologies are available for small farmers that can
            substantially raise their productivity and incomes if
            adapted to their farming systems. This demonstrates that
            modest injections of capital to information-starved rural
            communities has dramatic impacts on the livelihoods of
            farming families, and if extended more widely will lead to a
            second farmer-led wave in increased agricultural
            productivity and profitability to follow on the heels of the
            Green Revolution. Integrated, farmer-led extension drives
            the process enabling farming groups to access technology and
            market information and to develop mutually beneficial
            partnerships with agri-business and other providers. 2)
            Multi-provider models, such as the field extension teams
            piloted under this project, greatly improve the
            cost-effectiveness of publicly-funded extension. Field
            extension teams composed of government primary production
            agencies and NGO extension workers together with leading
            farmers, are highly effective in: (a) showing farmers how to
            organize and discover information for themselves; (b)
            enabling integrated farming systems solutions to improve
            rural livelihoods; (c) facilitating the emergence of private
            sector extension and adoption of "user pays"
            principles; (d) assisting government agencies and NGOs plan
            their activities to meet farmer needs; (e) increasing the
            cost effectiveness of publicly-funded extension; and (f)
            encouraging team building, and providing a focal point for
            specialist training in participative approaches to extension
            and agri-business planning. 3) Management structures such as
            the district extension committees which are set up to
            coordinate extension activities at the district level need
            both political and financial backing to survive beyond the
            life of the project. 4) To ensure high adoption rates among
            farmers, extension activities should focus on introducing
            and/or improving low-cost, highly profitable, market-led
            production and processing activities. 5) Monitoring and
            evaluation systems need to be established and given due
            importance by the Government during project design and
            closely followed during implementation. 6) Timely budget
            flows from central and local governments to the project
            implementing agencies down to field level should be ensured.
